  },
  "method": "First find the mass of calcium carbonate in the impure limestone: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g  0.840 = 4.20 g. Next calculate moles using n = m/Mr. From the atomic data, Mr(CaCO3) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 316.0 = 100.1, so n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol  0.0420 mol. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl  CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.0420 mol. Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 216.0 = 44.0, so mass of CO2 = nMr = 0.0420  44.0 = 1.85 g (maximum, since acid is in excess).",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "m(CaCO3) = sample mass  (percent/100)",
    "1 mol CaCO3  1 mol CO2 (from balanced equation)",
    "m = n  Mr"

}
